*[Bug 17213] [patch] detectCores() does not see multiple sockets on Linux*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17213>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Thanks. For reference, the issues with detecting the number of physical
processors from /proc/cpuinfo on Linux has been solved differently, it was
disabled (and documented as such - so only the number of logical processors is
reported). The output of /proc/cpuinfo is not reliable enough for automated
processing and may change at any time - after all it is not meant for automated
processing. The number of logical processors detected should be less error
prone and it is questionable how important the number of physical processors
really is (or should be) for user programs.

--- Comment #6 from Ella Kaye (<mailto:ella.kaye@gmail.com|ella.kaye@gmail.com>) ---
(In reply to Ivan Krylov from comment #5)
Under the patch, this will now generate the error message "invalid 'times'
argument, given the value of 'each'", whereas `rep(1:(2^31+1), times =
1:(2^31+3)` generates simply "invalid 'times' argument".

Do you consider that acceptable? The source code checks whether `length(times)
= length(x) * each` before it considers whether `sum(times)` is too big.
Changing that would be a bigger refactor of the code.

I suppose that if `times` is invalid without an interaction with `each`, then
it would be preferable if the error message doesn't mention each, but I think
it's OK with the current patch. This test case breaks `rep` in various ways, so
perhaps it doesn't matter so much which of the various possible error messages
it could generate shows up first. 

That said, I'm now seeing that `rep(1:(2^31+1), each = 2^31+2)` generates the
error "invalid 'times' argument" and that presents a different issue, given
that here `times` isn't user-specified and defaults to `1`, so it's definitely
not `times` that's the problem.

*[Bug 18434] Additional entries for tools::get_exclude_patterns()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18434>

Ivan Krylov (<mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |ikrylov@disroot.org

--- Comment #5 from Ivan Krylov (<mailto:ikrylov@disroot.org|ikrylov@disroot.org>) ---
`"\\.sw.$"` turned out to exclude too much, including [`*.swc` files containing
neuron shape
information](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2025-August/084123.html>).

Unless working on an 8.3 filesystem, Vim creates the swap files hidden.
(Additionally, an anonymous buffer may get an `_.s??` swap file on Windows
instead of `.s??` on Unix, but otherwise modern Windows behaves like Unix.)
This [suggests](<https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-devel/2025-August/084131.html>)
the following patterns:

```
--- src/library/tools/R/build.R (revision 88556)
+++ src/library/tools/R/build.R (working copy)
@@ -54,8 +54,11 @@
     c("^\\.Rbuildignore$",
       "(^|/)\\.DS_Store$",
       "^\\.(RData|Rhistory)$",
-      "~$", "\\.bak$", "\\.sw.$",
+      "~$", "\\.bak$",
       "(^|/)\\.#[^/]*$", "(^|/)#[^/]*#$",
+      ## Vim
+      "(^|/)([.][^/]+|_)?[.]sw[a-p]$",
+      "(^|/)([.][^/]+|_)?[.]s[a-v][a-z]$",
       ## Outdated ...
       "^TITLE$", "^data/00Index$",
       "^inst/doc/00Index\\.dcf$",
```

We may choose to err on the side of caution and only auto-exclude `*.sw[a-p]`
instead of the full range of potential Vim swap files starting with `.saa`.
